Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Botulinum Toxin Type A in Tibial Distraction Osteogenesis

Trial_Design.evidence: This double-blind, randomised controlled trial included 36 patients undergoing bilateral tibia lengthening

Participants.evidence: Participants met prespecified inclusion criteria, including undergoing stature lengthening with either lengthening over a nail or lengthening and then nailing.

Intervention.evidence: Each patient received a 200 IU BtX-A injection in one calf muscle, with the contralateral leg receiving a saline injection as a control.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the effect of Botulinum Toxin Type A (BtX-A) on reducing calf pain and improving range of motion (ROM) during tibial distraction osteogenesis.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the difference in calf pain measured by VAS scores and ROM of the knees and ankles, assessed until the end of the consolidation phase.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted at the leg level, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This double-blind, randomised controlled trial included 36 patients undergoing bilateral tibia lengthening from April 2010 to January 2011.

Result_Outcome.evidence: There were no significant differences in calf pain, knee and ankle ROM, or maximal calf circumferences between the treated and control legs at any time point.
